I have to this point been reluctant to join this thread. I am not going to debate in this I only want to set the facts strait don't try to sucker me in I will not bite.
 
 I am a firearms safety instructor and have extensive knowledge and experience with the particular type of gun that along with other factors facilitated this accident. Most if not all senseless accidents are not caused by a single event but by the culmination of a chain of factors, this one was no different. Had any one of the factors had been broken in the chain this boy would be alive, scared but alive. The father was the one that picked the gun thinking that the gun was small there for would be easy for the child to shoot (it was a Micro UZI). This was the first of a string of errors. The father wasn’t familiar with machine guns and would not have known the gun he picked is not a gun for an amateur to shoot let alone a child. The owner should have enquired as to who would be shooting the gun or if he did know he should have refused to let the kid shoot it and found a more appropriate one for him to shoot (the owner knows that gun better than anyone and would know that it was dangerous for any child to shoot that particular gun) error number two. The owner should have walked the gun up to the line and supervised the gun while the child shot, as it was the child was being supervised by someone who wouldn’t have known the capabilities of the child or the behavior of that gun error number three. The child was allowed to fire the gun from the hip the stock was not extended (this is just for accuracy it would have made no difference to the final out come whether it was extended or not) error number four. Had the stock been extended and shouldered the gun would have rocketed straight up in the air knocking the child to the ground he would have been bruised and scared but alive or if the gun had a barrel extension on it for the child to hold on to while firing from the hip the extension would have folded the Childs arm but it would have been slowed and would not have reached the angle to kill him and ripped the trigger out of his hand stopping the gun, he would be bruised with a sprained wrist, scared but still live. One more thing if the range officers had been educated on machine guns they would have known enough to stop it. There was a complete break down in reasonable caution and safety that caused this tragedy. The truly sad thing is it could have just as easily been a drowning or anything else that took his life and then no one would have noticed.
 
 This unfortunate accident has left others and me heart broken. I was there the day before with a number of others that had the experience to have prevented this were we there and saw the chain of events start. I don't think anyone of us would have hesitated to step in and take the bullet for him I know I would have.

Mr. Penfold, Mr. Brady-
 
 While I do value human life, I don't believe that we should be obsessed with saving a single individual, to the point that we're willing to take extreme measures just to try and protect the life of one person.
 
 I came from Britain where the mindset was "if it prevents the life of a single person, then we'll take away anything we possibly can to do it" and I can tell you that it simply doesn't work. There was even an effort by parliament to ban step ladders because too many people were falling from too great a height and dying.
 
 Yes this is a tragic accident, that can't be denied. But if you wish to talk about accidents, how many innocent people are mistakenly shot and killed by the police each year? Surely if protecting a single life is so important to you, you'd be pushing for the police to be as unarmed as our police, correct?
 
 Or...maybe you don't care about protecting lives, maybe you just care about exploiting the dead to make to try and advance your agendas. One of the most common, and most hated lines that I hear when supporters of gun control speak is "Think of the children!" yet if no children were dying, you wouldn't care about them, you wouldn't worry about them, and you wouldn't try and conjure up fear mongering tactics such as this.
 
 I honestly doubt that any of you truly care about saving the lives of children, otherwise you'd be pushing for a nationwide ban on swimming pools since the CDC statistics show that you're far more likely to drown than be killed with a bullet.
